Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 09:03AM Mahomet_mom wrote: I suggest that you get your own printed copy of the reports done on your condition.  Bring them with you to the new doc and ask for them to interpret.  Get cds of of the imaging done at the first place and have them sent (or hand carry) to the new one. That will save time and possibly money.  It will give them a preview of your breasts and enable them to begin to a review right away. Hang tough.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 01:24PM Mahomet_mom wrote: OK - so deep breath time.  This was also my diagnosis a year ago.  You will meet with a surgeon and oncologist to discuss options that are available to treat this.  This site has good information and you will want to go into your appointments with questions written down.  I'd suggest bringing someone with you to the appointments because frankly it is hard to listen and understand what is being discussed.  The emotions cause some 'static' in the communication process.  You may also meet a nurse who can assist you - in some areas they are called 'nurse navigators'.  They can be of help when other questions come to mind and can assist you in getting your various appointments, labs and other prep work done.  You will have some time to get things organized, you may want an opinion from another surgeon.  You don't want to drag this out forever, but you have time to get an understanding of things and feel as comfortable as possible as this unfolds. I suggest getting a written copy of the biopsy report and ask questions about characteristics of your cancer cells.  As you gather more information it is easier to focus on your own situation and how your cancer might be approached with various treatments beyond surgery, radiation and the like.  This is scary stuff but you are a strong woman and you will get through this.  Stay connected to us here.  We offer our support and strength to you.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 08:50AM Mahomet_mom wrote: Dear Hope, I suggest trying to take a very deep breath and letting the fear go, over and over.... Then make a list of questions and bring someone with you to the appointments.  Ask for a printed copy of the test results that have been done, the biopsy results, any labs, various scans etc.  Then ask the doctor(s) to interpret these for you.    In my case, not knowing what is going on just fuels the anxiety.  There is so much information available about diseases/conditions that it is hard to rein in your fears until there are some definites.  Then you can focus, fight, plan. You will get through this because you are a tough gal. And you have a lot of support here.  Take care...let us know how this unfolds.
